steps.title: Place the cooked edamame in a bowl.
steps.content: Place the cooked edamame in a bowl.

steps.title: Sprinkle it with cayenne pepper and soy sauce.
steps.content: Sprinkle it with cayenne pepper and soy sauce. Sprinkle 1/2 tsp. of cayenne pepper and 1 tsp. of soy sauce over the edamame for a spicy snack.

steps.title: Eat it.
steps.content: Eat it. To eat the edamame, just put one edamame pod in your mouth, slide out the edamame beans with your teeth, and discard the pods. If you'd rather not do this every time you at edamame, you can remove the beans from the pods first, and then you can place them in a bowl and garnish them with spices of your choice. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Store it.
steps.content: Store it. This edamame will hold in the refrigerator for at least two days.

steps.title: Bring 2 quarts of salted water to a boil.
steps.content: Bring 2 quarts of salted water to a boil. Throw at least 2 tbsp. of salt into the water. This is the first step to making this tasty edamame dip. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Put 12 oz.
steps.content: Put 12 oz. of fresh shelled edamame into the water.

steps.title: Return the water to a simmer and cook the edamame for 5 minutes.
steps.content: Return the water to a simmer and cook the edamame for 5 minutes. Cook them until they're cooked through and tender. Then, drain them with cold water. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Place the edamame in a food processor and pulse several times.
steps.content: Place the edamame in a food processor and pulse several times. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Add 1/2 cup of chopped cilantro to the processor and pulse again.
steps.content: Add 1/2 cup of chopped cilantro to the processor and pulse again.

steps.title: Add the remaining ingredients and pulse until they're puréed well.
steps.content: Add the remaining ingredients and pulse until they're puréed well. Add 1/2 cup of water, 1/4 cup of lime juice, 1-2 tsp. of salt, 5 shakes of Tabasco, and 3 drops of sesame oil to the processor and pulse until they're blended. If you'd like the dip to be a bit smoother, add a bit more water.

steps.title: Serve.
steps.content: Serve. Place this tasty edamame dip into a bowl and enjoy it with pita chips, carrots, or a variety of chips or veggies.

steps.title: Make the dressing.
steps.content: Make the dressing. Combine the lime juice, oils, garlic, and sugar in a small bowl. Place 3 tbsp. of lime juice, 2 tbsp. extra virgin olive oil, 2 tbsp. canola oil, 1 small pressed garlic clove, and ½ tsp. of sugar in a small bowl.

steps.title: Whisk the ingredients together.
steps.content: Whisk the ingredients together. Whisk the ingredients together to combine the flavors and set them aside.

steps.title: Place the edamame, corn, black beans, onion, and cilantro in a large bowl.
steps.content: Place the edamame, corn, black beans, onion, and cilantro in a large bowl. Place 2 cups of corn, 1 cup of cooked edamame soybeans, 1 15-oz. can of drained black beans, ½ cup of diced red onion, and ½ cup of chopped fresh cilantro in a large bowl.

steps.title: Pour the dressing over the vegetable mixture.
steps.content: Pour the dressing over the vegetable mixture. Gently toss the veggies and the dressing to combine the flavors. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Refrigerate.
steps.content: Refrigerate. Refrigerate this salad for at least an hour, or even overnight, for the flavors to fully blend. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Serve.
steps.content: Serve. Enjoy this cold salad as a side dish at any time.

steps.title: Put the diced asparagus in a bowl with 2 tbsp.
steps.content: Put the diced asparagus in a bowl with 2 tbsp. of water. Wash and dice the asparagus into 1" pieces first. This is the first step to making this edamame fried rice . [7] X Research source

steps.title: Microwave the bowl for 30 seconds.
steps.content: Microwave the bowl for 30 seconds. This will cook the asparagus slightly.

steps.title: Heat 3 tbsp.
steps.content: Heat 3 tbsp. of canola oil in a skillet. After the oil heats up for a minute or so, add the asparagus. Cook it for about a minute, making sure you don't burn the pieces.

steps.title: Add the garlic, powdered ginger, and pepper flakes to the mixture.
steps.content: Add the garlic, powdered ginger, and pepper flakes to the mixture. Cook 1 tbsp. of minced garlic, one pinch of ground ginger, and one pinch of red pepper flakes to the skillet and cook the ingredients together until the asparagus has started to turn brown.

steps.title: Add 3 cups of thawed frozen edamame to the mixture and cook for 5 minutes.
steps.content: Add 3 cups of thawed frozen edamame to the mixture and cook for 5 minutes. Stir the ingredients together, and then add 1 tbsp. of low sodium soy sauce and a tsp. of water to the rest of the ingredients. Add a bit more water if the ingredients start to dry up or burn a bit. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Stir in the rice and 3 diced scallions and cook for 1 more minute.
steps.content: Stir in the rice and 3 diced scallions and cook for 1 more minute. Stir the ingredients together to combine the flavors for 1 minute, or until the ingredients are cooked through. Then, remove the ingredients from the heat. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Serve.
steps.content: Serve. Season the rice with soy sauce and red pepper flakes to taste and enjoy it immediately. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Add it to stews or soups.
steps.content: Add it to stews or soups. Instead of using common vegetables, for example carrots or peas, use edamame beans as a substitution. It's a great addition in slow cooker soups as well. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Pair it with pasta or shellfish dishes.
steps.content: Pair it with pasta or shellfish dishes. If you're planning to have shrimp scampi or a very light pasta dish with seasonal vegetables, sprinkle some beans as a nice crunchy topping.
